generif.text: Peptide STEAP-292.2L (MLAVFLPIV) may have potential as an antitumor peptide vaccine.

STEAP mRNA is used here as a marker to evaluate biological samples from individuals suspected of having cancers, and may provide prognostic information useful in defining appropriate therapeutic options.
STEAP1 is over-expressed in breast cancer and down-regulated by 17beta-estradiol.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
STEAPs may represent novel markers of mesenchymal stem cells in man as well as mice.
Data suggest that zoledronic acid may affect cancer cells also by targeting the gene expression of STEAP.
Meta-analysis of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Studies suggest that activated human gammadelta T cells can efficiently present PRAME and STEAP1-derived epitopes and allow breaking tolerance against these tumor-associated self-antigens.
EWS-FLI1 mediated overexpression of STEAP1 increases the invasiveness and oxidative stress levels of Ewing tumor cells.
STEAP1 is associated with the invasive behavior and oxidative stress phenotype of Ewing tumors, an unanticipated oncogenic function of STEAP1.
A total of 62.3% of the Ewing's Sarcoma samples displayed detectable STEAP1 expression with predominant localization of the protein at the plasma membrane.
STEAP1 overexpression predicts improved outcome of Ewing's sarcoma patients, possibly due to enhanced sensitivity towards ROS-generating chemotherapeutics.
STEAP1 is down-regulated by dihydrotestosterone and estradiols in LNCaP cells and in rat prostate.
The findings provide evidence that STEAP1 is a biomarker of worse prognosis in prostate carcinomas patients.

Data indicate that six transmembrane epithelial antigen of the prostate 1 (STEAP1) is consistently overexpressed in malignant prostate tissue, namely adenocarcinoma and prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) lesions.
These findings highlight the ability of immuno-PET with (89)Zr-2109A to detect acute changes in STEAP1 expression
Data suggest a solid basis for further research into understanding how six-transmembrane epithelial antigen of prostate member 1 (STEAP1) activities may affect cancer progression.
High STEAP1 expression is associated with prostate cancer.
The expression of STEAP-1 is significantly associated with high-grade Gleason scores and seminal vesicle invasion of PCa.
Low STEAP1 expression was associated with Breast Cancer Metastasis.
we identified high STEAP1 transcript levels leading to reduced ROS production that prevented apoptosis via the NRF2 pathway in CRC cells as a pathological mechanism in CRC.
Six-transmembrane epithelial antigen of the prostate 1 expression promotes ovarian cancer metastasis by aiding progression of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition.
Cryo-electron microscopy structure and potential enzymatic function of human six-transmembrane epithelial antigen of the prostate 1 (STEAP1).
STEAP1 facilitates metastasis and epithelial-mesenchymal transition of lung adenocarcinoma via the JAK2/STAT3 signaling pathway.
The Tumor Suppressive Roles and Prognostic Values of STEAP Family Members in Breast Cancer.
A research of STEAP1 regulated gastric cancer cell proliferation, migration and invasion in vitro and in vivos.
Clinical significance of STEAP1 extracellular vesicles in prostate cancer.
Identification of a New Transcriptional Co-Regulator of STEAP1 in Ewing's Sarcoma.
Predictive potential of STEAP family for survival, immune microenvironment and therapy response in glioma.
The Prognostic Value and Immunological Role of STEAP1 in Pan-Cancer: A Result of Data-Based Analysis.
STEAP1 regulation and its influence modulating the response of LNCaP prostate cancer cells to bicalutamide, enzalutamide and apalutamide.
Inhibition of STEAP1 ameliorates inflammation and ferroptosis of acute lung injury caused by sepsis in LPS-induced human pulmonary microvascular endothelial cells.
Proteomic analysis of STEAP1 knockdown in human LNCaP prostate cancer cells.
Six Transmembrane Epithelial Antigen 1 as a Prognostic Biomarker in Carcinomas: A Meta-Analysis.

name: STEAP family member 1
other_names: six transmembrane epithelial antigen of the prostate 1
summary: This gene is predominantly expressed in prostate tissue, and is found to be upregulated in multiple cancer cell lines. The gene product is predicted to be a six-transmembrane protein, and was shown to be a cell surface antigen significantly expressed at cell-cell junctions. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
